guild.description:
"For God so loved the world, that He gave His only begotten Son, that whoever believes in Him shall not perish, but have eternal life. For God did not send the Son into the world to judge the world, but that the world might be saved through Him. He who believes in Him is not judged; he who does not believe has been judged already, because he has not believed in the name of the only begotten Son of God. This is the judgment, that the Light has come into the world, and men loved the darkness rather than the Light, for their deeds were evil. For everyone who does evil hates the Light, and does not come to the Light for fear that his deeds will be exposed. But he who practices the truth comes to the Light, so that his deeds may be manifested as having been wrought in God."

May all personally encounter the presence and attention of the Lord God. 

Curiosity, questions, discussion, and prayer requests are welcome.

body:
Read it, liked it.

Remember, at the very outset of his ministry - the temptations in the desert....Satan declares that God has given to the devil the power to choose the leaders of every empire (and thus Satan offers to crown Jesus over them). Jesus says that nothing will cause him to commit such a sin. He DOES NOT SAY that Satan is wrong.

body:
> The outcome of the Council of Nicaea stated that Jesus Christ was the son of God and that he was to be treated as a divine figure. This went against Christ’s insistence that he was only a messenger and that people should follow his message, not worship him. There is a great deal of controversy surrounding the divinity of Christ, and many say that he didn’t want organized churches in his name.

Doesn't this contradict the Bible? Jesus was thought to be divine, and their churches were organized.

body:
He was clearly thought to be divine but their churches were not organized any more than a club meeting. In fact, churches didn't even exist yet. The first references to an organized church structure is in the forgeries 1 & 2 Timothy and Titus, outside of those they held secret house and underground meetings.

> This went against Christ’s insistence that he was only a messenger and that people should follow his message, not worship him.

I don't recall that, though he did place more *emphasis* on his message than worshiping him, but the thing is it can't really be followed without doing that.

> many say that he didn’t want organized churches in his name.

I could see this, assuming "organized" means institutional. The only times he said the opposite was in John 20:21-23 and Matthew 16:18-19, both suspiciously interrupting the current subject of the text and written in a different style than the rest of the gospels. These passages basically give Peter and the 12 disciples God-level authority which definitely sounds off. The rest of the time Jesus was constantly criticizing the organized synagogues and religious systems of the jewish leaders, instead praising those individuals who had faith.

body:
We are made in the image of a libertarian King. So we are called to all be libertarian kings.

>Revelation 1:5 And from Jesus Christ, who is the faithful witness, and the first begotten of the dead, and the prince of the kings of the earth. Unto him that loved us, and washed us from our sins in his own blood,

>6 And **hath made us kings** and priests unto God and his Father; to him be glory and dominion for ever and ever. Amen.

>7 Behold, he cometh with clouds; and every eye shall see him, and they also which pierced him: and **all kindreds of the earth shall wail because of him. Even so, Amen.**
body_html:
We are made in the image of a libertarian King. So we are called to all be libertarian kings.

Revelation 1:5 And from Jesus Christ, who is the faithful witness, and the first begotten of the dead, and the prince of the kings of the earth. Unto him that loved us, and washed us from our sins in his own blood,

6 And hath made us kings and priests unto God and his Father; to him be glory and dominion for ever and ever. Amen.

7 Behold, he cometh with clouds; and every eye shall see him, and they also which pierced him: and all kindreds of the earth shall wail because of him. Even so, Amen.

body:
Authenticity of Revelation aside, the KJV has a mistranslation here. It actually says "and has made us **a kingdom**, priests to the god and his father. The glory *is* to him, and the might into the ages of the ages, amen/אמן (truly)".

There is only 1 king. Read 1 Samuel 8 for more about what God thinks of earthly kings.

parent.body:
Authenticity of Revelation aside, the KJV has a mistranslation here. It actually says "and has made us **a kingdom**, priests to the god and his father. The glory *is* to him, and the might into the ages of the ages, amen/אמן (truly)".

There is only 1 king. Read 1 Samuel 8 for more about what God thinks of earthly kings.

body:
>Also βασιλειαν is singular so if it means king that'd be literally saying "and has made us a king" which makes no sense.

It's saying He has "made us a kingdom." IMO it's both a single kingdom for us all, the world, as well as for each our individual kingdoms. We all have our own specialty, our own dominion; he gave us each a unique seal.
There are plenty of other references to our royalty in the Bible:
>1 Peter 2:9, NIV: "But you are a chosen people, a **royal** priesthood, a holy nation, God's special possession, that you may declare the praises of him who called you out of darkness into his wonderful light."

body:
It's pretty clear to me, every time we are called royalty it is implying that we have the dominion of rulership. That's what royalty means. Even most princes were given lands to rule over, that was common practice. In Rev 17:14 he's called King of kings, lord of lords, implying that we are kings and lords ourselves.

And this is the only way it makes sense, if we are made in the image of a King, that means we are Kings. There's no grey area IMO...

body:
>You're confusing this temporary world with eternity. 

What's your point? We are called kings, he is king of kings. We are called royal priests, we are given a kingdom. It doesn't say anything about this world or eternity, so I don't see why you're trying to apply it to only one of the two.

>"King of kings and lord of lords" is also **just** an expression 

I would be careful of being dismissive or reducing the Bible's meanings to only 'just' one favored interpretation. That's the starting point for religious fundamentalism. It says King of Kings, that literally is *not* 'just' saying "He's a really important dude, yo."

parent.body:
>You're confusing this temporary world with eternity. 

What's your point? We are called kings, he is king of kings. We are called royal priests, we are given a kingdom. It doesn't say anything about this world or eternity, so I don't see why you're trying to apply it to only one of the two.

>"King of kings and lord of lords" is also **just** an expression 

I would be careful of being dismissive or reducing the Bible's meanings to only 'just' one favored interpretation. That's the starting point for religious fundamentalism. It says King of Kings, that literally is *not* 'just' saying "He's a really important dude, yo."

body:
Instructions for establishing our petty kingdoms on earth:

>Ps 2:7 I will declare the decree: the Lord hath said unto me, Thou art my Son; this day have I begotten thee. *Ask of me, and I shall give thee the heathen for thine inheritance, and the uttermost parts of the earth for thy possession.*

Ask God for your inheritance.

>Rev 5:9 And they sung a new song, saying, Thou art worthy to take the book, and to open the seals thereof: for thou wast slain, and hast redeemed us to God by thy blood out of every kindred, and tongue, and people, and nation; And *hast made us unto our God kings and priests: and we shall reign on the earth.*

Through Christ's power working in us do we establish our inheritance.

>Rev 2:23 And I will kill her children with death; and all the churches shall know that I am he which searcheth the reins and hearts: and I will give unto every one of you according to your works.
But unto you I say, and unto the rest in Thyatira, as many as have not this doctrine, and which have not known the depths of Satan, as they speak; I will put upon you none other burden.
But that which ye have already hold fast till I come.
And he that overcometh, and keepeth my works unto the end, *to him will I give power over the nations:
And he shall rule them with a rod of iron;* as the vessels of a potter shall they be broken to shivers: even as I received of my Father.

We will be given according to our hearts and our works. Hold on to what you already have. Overcome adversity and preserve the works of God. Be stern when necessary and stand up for what is right, even against seemingly insurmountable odds.

body:
What would be the value in giving us instructions that we couldn't use? Where do you see that this is not for the current world? It is for both worlds. 

As above, so below. We are made in His image. Or as Matthew puts it:

>Matthew 6:10
10 your kingdom come, your will be done, **on earth as it is in heaven**.

>another translation - Matthew 6:10
10 Set the world right; Do what's best - as above, so below.

body:
>These things will be accomplished on earth as in heaven, but in a different realm.

This doesn't make any sense. "On earth as in heaven." We are on earth now. And you are trying to say it is not for this earth, but a different earth? 

Ultimately that would mean that the Bible is full of useless, irrelevant information for our current situation. Sounds like a *really bad* assumption for a Christian to make. And you haven't cited any scripture supporting you like I had asked. Being in the world but not of it does not contradict what I just said.

body:
Israel didn't have a king, that doesn't mean Israel was in anarchy. It was a group of tribes. Tribes are governmental structures.

The point is we are to exert rulership and dominion over this world via love, self-sacrifice and a union between the living Christ and our souls. And when we do this properly, dominion is established *on this earth, here and now*.

That doesn't mean to enslave our neighbors. But I think it does involve some form of libertarian government.

For everyone who does evil hates the Light, and does not come to the Light for fear that his deeds will be exposed. But he who practices the truth comes to the Light, so that his deeds may be manifested as having been wrought in God."
